repository.corpname: M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives

did.unittitle: Women Against War Records
did.abstract: This collection documents the founding, day-to-day operations, and events and projects of Women Against War, an organization based in the Capital Region of New York.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is unrestricted.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Eleanor Stein donated paper records in 2020. Mickie Lynn and Maud Easter arranged for the donation of the Women Against War Waging Peace blog in 2021. In 2024, Maud Easter donated paper records, the Yahoo Groups email correspondence, and mixed A/V materials, including CDs, DVDs, cassettes, and videocassettes, and Trudy Quaif donated videos she had of interviews with longtime Women Against War members.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged alphabetically. There are no series.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Women Against War was formed in 2002 by a network of Capital District New York women who mobilized against the United States government's plan to go to war with Iraq. Their first public event was a gathering that took place on the steps of the Legislative Office Building in Albany on December 5, 2002, where the group put out an open call for participants in their Women's Fast for Peace. The Fast for Peace was ultimately a continuous five-month event where each participant fasted for a twenty four hour period and documented the experience in a shared journal. The group's initial focus was on the cost of the Iraq War to women and children, but, since its inception, Women Against War has expanded their focus through projects and events on Iraqi refugees, Iran, Afghanistan, Korea, the Patriot Act, Islamophobia, and U.S. military spending and recruitment at large. They have become a vital participant in the larger national and international peace and justice movement through their various projects and affiliations, advocating for changed U.S. foreign policies through lobbying, leafletting, billboard and yard sign campaigns, traveling exhibits, vigils, media outreach, and educational events. They have collaborated with other prominent peace organizations, including the American Friends Service Committee and Code Pink. In 2006, a sub-group of Women Against War called Grannies for Peace was established, inspired by the New York City based organization Granny Peace Brigades. Grannies for Peace's first event was a demonstration at the Albany Military Recruiting Office in Colonie Center Mall on February 14, 2006.
Additional information about the organization can be found on Women Against War's archived website, http://womenagainstwar.org/Archive/index.htm.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

Identification of specific item, series, box, folder, Women Against War Records, 2001-2023. M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives, University Libraries, University at Albany, State University of New York (hereafter referred to as the Women Against War Records).

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was processed in 2025 by Gabriella Baratier.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related collections include the Eleanor Stein Papers (apap383). Stein, a lawyer and environmental activist, was a founding member of Women Against War.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: The physical materials in the collection include meeting minutes, correspondence, membership lists, fliers, journals, photographs, newspaper clippings, publications, and A/V documenting the activities of Women Against War. Particularly well-represented are the records from the 2002/2003 Women's Fast For Peace, including journal entries by each participant; the meeting minutes, correspondence, and events for the projects Grannies for Peace and Pathways to Peace; and the meeting minutes of the Steering Committee. The digital materials in the collection include the Waging Peace Wordpress Blog, which appeared on the Albany Times Union website from 2008-2021, interviews with three longtime members, and Yahoo Groups email correspondence from 2002 to 2021.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: This page may contain links to digital objects. Access to these images and the technical capacity to download them does not imply permission for re-use. Digital objects may be used freely for personal reference use, referred to, or linked to from other web sites.
Researchers do not have permission to publish or disseminate material from these collections without permission from an archivist and/or the copyright holder.

The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming to the laws of copyright. Some materials in these collections may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) and/or by the copyright or neighboring-rights laws of other nations. More information about U.S. Copyright is provided by the Copyright Office. Additionally, re-use may be restricted by terms of University Libraries gift or purchase agreements, donor restrictions, privacy and publicity rights, licensing and trademarks.
The Department of Special Collections and Archives is eager to hear from any copyright owners who are not properly identified so that appropriate information may be provided in the future.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This item contains multiple listservs from the Women Against War inbox. The four listservs have been split into individual subseries, which have also been split out by year for ease of access.
